reviewText:
As someone who harbors a ticklespot for scatalogical humor, I found myself giggling right away.

And then when I read some of the outraged, disgusted reviews of this game it made me laugh harder. To think there are adults just waiting for their chance to denounce other adults because they still find the crude simplicity of poop jokes funny.

As if deriving any kind of good nature from a bowel movement or a fart is immediate grounds for being stripped of all noble status or perceived brilliance.

And yet any well-read person will know that toilet humor appears in the works of Shakespeare; King Lear, Comedy of Errors, Othella, Two Gentleman From Verona are just a few examples. In Aristophanes' THE CLOUDS, a character describes his bowel movements to Socrates as thunder passing through him. Highly celebrated author Jonathon Swift wrote an entire pamphlet on the benefit of flatulence.

There's even a story in 1001 Arabian Nights Tales of a man who flees his wedding after letting out a long, noticeable fart at the ceremony. If that doesn't strike your ancient fancy, in Dante Alighieri's THE INFERNO, near the end of chapter XXI, we're told of a demon mobilizing his army by using his butt as a trumpet.

So if you're one of the special little snowflakes who hates this game because it dares to use bodily functions as a comedic template, then my advice is not to have children. Like, ever. Seriously. Don't procreate. You'll hate yourself for having to change diapers and your child will resent you for growing up in a household where they aren't allowed to laugh when somebody farts.

reviewText:
Veni, vidi, faeci.

I came, I saw, I pooped.

There's Poop in my Soup has you playing as a small child running along some overhead fire escape platforms and wiring, as they launch faeces from their weird v*gina mouth orifice thing and rain it down onto the unsuspecting pedestrians below. Using a limited number of poops, hit as many as you can in a row without missing to build up your multiplier (and, ultimately, your score) and permanently unlock extra bonuses which carry over into all future attempts of that stage. Bonuses include additional poojectiles/attempts, extra pedestrians to aim for, and special moves to maximise the filthy, disgusting carnage and make each go easier than the last.

This is a globe-trotting poop adventure, as you let rip with your tyrannical turd tirade upon New York, Beijing, and Paris, and terrorise as many local stereotypes as possible. There's a checklist of targets or objectives in each location, too, which also carries over across multiple attempts, aaaaaand............... yeah... That's it. That's the entire game, right there.

There's only about 40-50 minute's worth of gameplay to complete everything, or Steam Workshop content to stretch it our a little more if you're bothered, but aside from some easy achievements or trading cards for those who actually care about them, there's nothing else here. Controls are OK enough, using WASD to move from side to side and adjust targeting, though the actual hit detection feels kinda wonky and doesn't always seem to land where you're aiming. It's not a huge deal, but it is an issue you'll definitely notice.

It's dumb as all hell, it's tasteless, it's cheap, it's puerile and it's tacky - but it's fun. And it's well aware of all that, too. If pooping on people from up on high seems like a larf to you and you have an extra hour to kill and a spare euro/dollar/whatever burning a hole in your pocket, then this is the game for you. For everyone else?... NO POOP FOR YOU!

reviewText: In these days of predictable storylines, recycled game mechanics, countless sequels, and cheap gimmicks, it is nice to see one developer who remains steady and true that the core intents that the video game industry has swayed from in recent years. Even in the early days of games like Spacewar on the PDP-1 in 1962, people had the same question: Can I poop on it? Sadly, due to the limits of technology, prejudices amongst retailers, and unfair censorship, this question could not be fulfilled. Thankfully, one developer dares to push the brown envelope and answer this age old question. Some may criticize this game, they may even call it crap, of which I would say, exactly. It is rare to be blessed with such artistic creativity in any form of media, let alone video games. So I raise my glass a safe distance from our defecating hero, and salute you for answering the question gamers have had since the conception of video games.

reviewText:
First of all, let's get this out of the way: you're an idiot if you're leaving a review to bash this game because of what it is - a game where you ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• on people. It isn't ruining the gaming industry, there isn't a problem with Steam Greenlight. Go crawl back under the rock you emerged from.

Now that that is out of the way, There's Poop In My Soup is a short casual game about being an ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• (pun intended) and pooping on people in different ways. You have two means of attack per level - your normal poop, where you shoot a poop log in correlation to where the highlighted position is, and a special attack that varies per level from a poop bomb to poop fireworks to a poop fountain spewing out of your butt face. The gameplay is simplistic and your main intention is to finish the objectives in the level and score as many points as possible. As you increase your combo of successful poop assaults, an upbeat musical piece starts playing louder and louder as the level gets more erratic with people running from your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•-storm.

At the core, this game is entertaining for what it is. TPIMS doesn't try to be anything to be anything it isn't. However, I will say that the screenshots the game provides are misleading: you cannot change the camera angle which is a real bummer. The other issue is that the area that you highlight to defecate on is not always the area where your poop lands - specifically on the last two levels, the game seems to be less and less accurate as you advance. Whether this is intentional or not, it feels like a design flaw. When you get very high combos, the people sometimes glitch out, their necks stretching across the level or mangled around the piles of poop covered citizens. One more problem that I noticed is that the game saves your progress badly - exiting out won't lose your progress, but to gain it back, you have to individually go into the levels and back out again to regain access to attacks or later levels.

For the price, I can recommend it. It offered me a bit over an hour of gameplay including getting all the achievements, which were not difficult to get.

The dialogue is my biggest complaint, but It's not that big a of a deal in retrospect. My other complaint is that quests often have 1 ending, I would love to choose from several endings but I do not expect this for every quest.

The Game is beautiful, it's got a great feel to it and I love the way the world is set up. The dirt may be a boring brown but you find that the Post/Pre-War buildings have a nice color scheme and It makes the game that much more nice looking. As for people who are underwhelmed by the map, C'mon? If you want to be underwhelmed look at New Vegas. The City was an empty pile with 50% of the buildings being unenterable. It had a total of 6 nice looking buildings, That was it!

The Power Armor makes you feel like an absolute BEAST! I don't mind that they gave me a Minigun and Power Armor in the first 20 mins of the game because the Armor is in bad shape to start with (and after killing a Death Claw it's in worse shape) and after killing everything in that mission I only had 21 shots left on the gun. I droped it because who wants to carry around a useless (and heavy) weapon. The people who are questioning the use of Power Armor in the first 20 mins should take into consideration that it's a way of giving you an incentive to find, craft, and customize your own set(s). In Fallout New Vegas I never bothered with Power Armor because I already had some cool cowboy stuff, and it didn't do that much for me anyways. Not to mention that it looked pretty bad too.

reviewText:
There's Poop in my Soup is a short-lived casual title where you play the role of a toddler who has a butt for a face; yes, much like that amazing South Park episode. The entire goal of the game is to fling your poop down onto unsuspecting people, all the while meeting goals from your To-Poop checklist.

The game has simple enough mechanics; you maneuver left, right, forward, and backward, all the while deciding who your next poo victim will be. Will it be the mother pushing the stroller? How about the taxi driver? Maybe that unsuspecting, well groomed poodle? It's ultimately up to you, and each person or item you hit will further your combo and score. Once you unlock a set number of goals, you will unlock a special power and a new stage. The power that is unlocked is dependent on which level you are playing on; New York City has a poop bomb, Beijing has poop fireworks, and Paris has Runny Tummy... basically, diarrhea.

Yes, there are only three levels in There's Poop in My Soup, which is a big downfall of the title. Each level, along with all of their To-Poop checklist goals, and the achievements, can be completed within 40 minutes to an hour. After that, there is little to no replayability. I will say, however, that the game itself runs great and I had no issues with glitches, bugs, or crashes. For a buck o' nine CAD, it's not a bad ride to take; there have certainly been worse in the last few months. I recommend this title since it's a fun and not-so-serious excursion, plus you can imagine pooping on your idiot coworkers... YES CINDY, I'M TALKING ABOUT YOU.

There's Poop in My Soup is rough around the edges and could use some polish, but it has enough charm and humor to be worth the 89 cents I paid for it.

This is basically a sort of space-invaders meets physics chaos type of game. You stand on top of buildings and drop poop on unsuspecting passersby. That might sound like it could get dull, and the game does have a lifespan, but there's a surprising amount to be discovered. There is a huge amount of different trick shots and animations to discover. Certain characters react to the poop differently and you can bounce the poop off of awnings. If you poop on a certain number of people, you unlock little perks, such as more people walking around, or alternate poop weapons. As you only have a finite number of poops per session, you have to replay the level a few times to unlock things. The alternate poop weapons are pretty powerful and allow you to really begin upping your score, but they sacrifice accuracy, so specific outcomes might be harder to predict. Even though you unlock things through the number of people you poop on, the true goal is to get the highest score you can. The fact that you have to replay the levels to achieve the number of people pooped on does lengthen the game, but it does make the early stages a bit slow, and the game truly hits its stride when you've got the maximum people walking around. That said, it is important to start slowly so you can learn each area, so it's not too bad of a progression.

The game's biggest asset is its charm. The graphical style is cute and hilarious. I love the weird, springy-haired guy who drops the poop, and the random citizens are equally memorable. I love the sound it makes when you poop. The visual style on the menus is clean and slick looking. The ragdoll physics add to the chaos in so many ways that even the developer might not have foreseen. One time I pooped on a guy and he ran out into the street and got hit by a car, only to have his body flung over the buildings. There were several moments where I had genuine, gut laughter from either the physics, the animations, or some secret thing that the game snuck into a level. It's crude stuff, but the game never feels mean-spirited and it lets you in on the joke. On that level, I definitely reccomend this game for its entertainment value.

The game's biggest failings are in its technical merits. The framerate is choppy and the game feels a bit unoptimized. My PC can max out most games at 60fps, so I should have no problem running a game like this. It does seem to smooth out after playing for a few rounds, but there's no reason for a game like this to lag. The other big issue is that there is not controller support. You have to aim with WASD and this feels a bit too clunky and imprecise to always get the exact shot I'm going for. Most of the time it's not too much of an issue, but it does hold the game back a bit. In a game like this where movement is part of the challenge, it would probably be too easy if you could aim with the mouse, but I think analogue stick movement would be the perfect middleground. I also think the camera on the New York level might benefit from being pulled out a bit, as when you try to aim into the extreme foreground, you can't see where you're actually aiming. The China level does rectify this however.

There's Poop in My Soup isn't perfect, but for 89 cents it is a funny and charming way to kill a few minutes. The game's biggest issues seem like they could easily be solved with a patch or two, and I hope the developer will keep working on this. It has issues, but I like it.

reviewText:
I want to start by saying that a key was given to me by the developer, but this in no way affected my review.

I genuinely enjoy this game. It's simple, it's easy to play, and it's a lot of fun. And you get to poop on people all around the world. What more could you possibly want?

I see a lot of people compare this game to Muddy Heights. Yes, both games feature a goal of pooping on people from the top of a building. But beyond that, they're different games. However, I do know that different people like different things, and this game is definitely not for everyone. But if you have a sense of (poop) humor, you'll agree that this game is very fun. Not to mention, it's extremely cheap. Well worth it.
